title: (x) wide square futuristic sans with wobbly edges - Boom Box {Dav}
content:
Howdy!  
Just recreating a logo for a client who only has a printed version of their logo available and hoping someone may be able to ID it or something similar for me!

Many Thanks,  
Paul.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Untitled-1.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081010003549/http:/typophile.com/files/Untitled-1_16.jpg) | 17.01 KB |

 [‹ (x) Grape Creek lapidary font - Skia {Dav}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081010003549/http:/typophile.com/node/21385 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for old Letraset catalogs ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081010003549/http:/typophile.com/node/21348 "Go to next forum topic")
author: pbags

comments.content:
Hi Paul

I think it’s very similar to [Eurostile](http://web.archive.org/web/20081010003549/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&font_categories=1&font_categories_search=font_name_search&searchstr=eurostile) or [Microgramma](http://web.archive.org/web/20081010003549/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&font_categories=1&font_categories_search=font_name_search&searchstr=microgramma), just with various bits chopped out of them.

Hi Ben,  
Thanks for the response - the characters in Eurostile or Microgramma are much more hard edged than the one on the logo (E, F, L & D) - they’re quite different and curved...

but thanks anyhow...

Anyone else care to enlighten me?? (please!!)

Thanks Dav!

Much appreciated.

Cheers,  
Paul.
